questionListItems.title: What information should be included in the Annual Report?

answer.body:
The annual report of a charity should be prepared in accordance with the requirement set out in the Charities (Accounts and Annual Report) Regulations. The annual report should contain the following:

 

(a)  Information relating to the charity or its governing board members or officers, which includes:

  • Description of the instrument setting up the charity (e.g. society, company or trust deed);

  • Singapore Unique Entity Number (UEN) of the charity;

  • Registered address of the charity;

  • Particulars of the governing board members/management committee; and

  • Names of advisors of the charity (e.g. bankers, lawyers, auditors, etc).

 

(b)  The report by the governing board, which states:

  • An explanation of the objectives of the charity;

  • The policies adopted during the financial year;

  • A review of the activities carried out by the charity during the financial year;

  • Review of financial state; and

  • Future plans and commitments. 

 

 (c) Financial Statements

 

**You may refer to the “Annual Report Illustrative Template Guide” (“AR Template”) on Charity Portal which will provide some guidance on the mandatory disclosure required by the Charities Act and Regulations, as well as best practices for transparency and disclosure.

questionListItems.title: Can the Annual Report be in other languages other than English?

answer.body: If the charity has difficulties in reporting their activities in English, it can report in other languages. However, the name of the charity reflected in the Annual Report has to be in English.

questionListItems.title: Must the annual submissions be submitted by a charity/ IPC Board member?

answer.body: No. The Board can authorise any personnel from the charity/IPC to submit the statutory returns.  The designated personnel must make a declaration before submitting the checklist.

questionListItems.title: What is the Governance Evaluation Checklist?

answer.body: The Governance Evaluation Checklist covers the key guidelines in the Code of Governance for Charities and IPCs. Charities should read the GEC in conjunction with the Code of Governance and consider all applicable principles and guidelines. It is mandatory under the Charities (Accounts and Annual Report) Regulations 2011 for all registered charities and IPCs to file their GEC as part of their annual submissions for financial years starting on or after 1 January 2018.

questionListItems.title: Which charities are excluded from the Governance Evaluation Checklist submission?

answer.body:
The following charities do not need to submit the Governance Evaluation Checklist


  1. Any charity which does not have IPC status and whose gross annual receipts or total expenditure, whichever is higher, in any of the last two financial years is less than $50,000; and

  2. Exempt Charities and self-funded Grantmakers, which in each case, does not have IPC status, such as philanthropic foundations funded with private family or institutional money.

 

However, we strongly encourage these registered charities to refer to the Code and apply the principles for good governance.

questionListItems.title: Is it compulsory to comply with all Code guidelines in the Governance Evaluation Checklist? What if a charity/IPC is unable to comply with the Code guidelines?

answer.body: The Code of Governance guidelines are good practices to help charities and IPCs manage themselves effectively and mitigate governance risks. Hence, charities and IPCs are encouraged to comply wherever possible. The Code operates on the principle of “comply or explain”. Where charities or IPCs are unable to comply with certain Code guidelines or where guidelines are not applicable to the charity or IPC, they must provide an explanation. Some charities may not be able to comply with certain guidelines because they are in the process of working towards compliance. This could be an explanation for non-compliance. Alternatively, some charities may even exceed the guidelines in the Code. It may also be that some Code guidelines do not easily relate to the circumstances of a particular charity. The charity should explain these circumstances in the checklist.

questionListItems.title: Is there a minimum score which charities/IPCs would be required to attain in the Governance Evaluation Checklist?

answer.body: There is no minimum score required as we acknowledge that charities or IPCs may need time to adopt the Code guidelines. Nevertheless, charities or IPCs must provide explanations to justify non-compliance of particular Code guidelines.

questionListItems.title: Can charities/IPCs update their previous Governance Evaluation Checklist submissions?

answer.body: Charities are not able to update to or delete their previously submitted Governance Evaluation Checklists themselves. However, should charities need to make any changes to their previous submissions, please email mccy_charities@mccy.gov.sg for our officers’ assistance.

questionListItems.title: Must charities/IPCs submit a new Governance Evaluation Checklist every year?

answer.body: Yes. Charities and IPCs must submit a new Governance Evaluation Checklist online annually within 6 months from the end of their financial year. The charities’ governing boards should take the opportunity to conduct an annual review of their governance practices and work towards complying with the Code guidelines, where applicable.

questionListItems.title: Why are some Code guidelines not covered in the online Governance Evaluation Checklist?

answer.body: For simplicity in reporting to Sector Administrators, the online checklist only includes the key Code guidelines, depending on the IPC status and size of the charity.  Nevertheless, charities and IPCs are encouraged to adopt all applicable guidelines in the Code of Governance which may not be in the online Evaluation Checklist.

questionListItems.title: Are there penalties if charities/IPCs do not submit the annual report/financial statements/ Governance Evaluation Checklist within 6 months from the end of their financial year?

answer.body: Charities and IPCs are required to submit the annual submissions to their respective Sector Administrator annually for review. If charities/IPCs require a longer period of time to submit the reports, they should write to the Sector Administrators for a mutually agreed deadline. The request for extension will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. Sector Administrators will take into account the submission status of the annual submissions in assessing the application and extension of IPC status.

questionListItems.title: What is an Online Financial Summary (OFS)?

answer.body: The Online Financial Summary (OFS) serves as a summary of the charity’s key financial information posted on the Charity Portal for public viewing. It is submitted as part of the charities' submission of Annual Reports (including financial statements and the appropriate Governance Evaluation Checklist) within 6 months from the end of each financial year of a charity. The OFS should be approved by the governing board members of a charity prior to submission to the Commissioner of Charities via the Charity Portal. Completing the OFS is part of the Office of the Commissioner of Charities’ on-going efforts to help charities improve their accountability and transparency and to enhance public confidence in the charity sector.

questionListItems.title: Who is required to submit the Online Financial Summary (OFS) ?

answer.body:
All IPCs are required to submit OFS.


All non-IPC charities with gross income or total expenditure exceeding $500,000 are required to submit OFS.

questionListItems.title: Who are exempted from submitting the Online Financial Summary (OFS)?

answer.body:
The following entities are exempted:

  1. Non-IPC charities with gross income and total expenditure not exceeding $500,000 (regardless of legal status (i.e. CLG, Society or Others)).

  2. Non-IPC charities which are self-funded grantmakers

questionListItems.title: What are the requirements on reporting on overseas expenditures, capital outlay and remittance of funds as agents? Why does the Office of the COC require charities to disclose overseas expenditure, capital outlay and remittance of funds as an agent or trustee?

answer.body: The reporting requirement forms part our on-going efforts to improve accountability of the charity sector and allows the Office of the COC to strengthen our oversight of the funds that charities remit or apply for overseas purposes. Charities are required to provide information about overseas expenditure, capital outlay, as well as remittance of funds received as an agent that is spent in, remitted to or benefitting locations outside Singapore. The reporting requirement applies to all charities which are required to submit the OFS. Such reporting will include the total quantum of financial resources applied overseas as well as the list of countries in which the overseas expenditure/capital outlay/remittance of funds are applied/remitted to, or where the overseas beneficiaries and partners are located. For remittances of funds as agents, charities will also be required to disclose the names of the overseas recipients.
